Title: Chapter 4 - Level Up!
Comment:
This is exactly how it works, only killing. Using skills levels up the skill itself, but to level up your class there is no shortcut, only killing things. Crafters are indeed a rare commodity, although they do not need to level up their class to have their main skill at a high level.

Most livestock is indeed level 1 or 2, giving very little xp, though the xp requirements for the first few levels are really low, so it adds up over time and a villager might reach about level 15 at some point just by virtue of killing chickens for food over their whole life. It's not that killing something of a lower level gives no experience, but it very rapidly gives increasingly less as the level gap widens. Keep in mind anything the narrator says when in Sofia's pov is still only really what Sofia experiences but doesn't actively think in phrases, she's sometimes straight up wrong or make false assumptions.

Either way, the reality of this system is that most humans won't even reach level 10 in their lifetime, by design. As for how anyone could possibly still get experience at higher levels without having to hunt that one wolf that decimated half the kingdom's sheeps for xp, or resorting to mass murder, it's a very simple case of not every species/race/individual being born at level 1.

I can't say much more about the why or how the system ended up like this without spoiling major plot points, so this will have to do for now (｀• ω •´)ｂ

Alright, so, I can't give a definite canon health number, but I can slightly correct a few things here, though I must say, you did a great job with the info available (▼∀▼)

So, the actual hp multiplier for most fighter classes is x2.5, so they have 50 at level one, and get 50 more per level (Only Sofia's mana stat doesn't work like that because it's so bugged, where she had 5000 at level one and gets 500 per level)

So the base health at level 100 would be 5000. Now, Pareth is a very special case, because he has two modifiers. In Holy Skeleton's description it says : "Physical and magical capabilities are influenced by the current bones. "

Which is rather vague, but the actual meaning is the stats are altered to better represent that of the type of original creature whose skeleton it's occupying (with a range from -50% to +50% depending on the skeleton) in this case the Elven skeleton is pretty close to an human so it would only be a few additional percents. (This part of the skill also represents that he can't properly use the sword without hands etc but that's details)

Next is the blessing, which is actually a linear scaling of 100 flat Health and Strength points per kg and not a % buff. But you got the weight correct, so in total, Pareth's health at the time was actually a tiny bit over 9000 ;)

Which is a big amount, but also he had no armor whatsoever so the Siren still absolutely destroyed him. Though he did tank a few hits. You can see how he got annihilated at the end,supposedly by some sort of water spell, when Sofia only took about 300 dmg from the water ball spell. So yeah, armor is a very big deal too.

Now this makes me realize I screwed up with the scaling of [Heal undead] (which I already changed a few times...) so I'll have to go back to look into it...

Anyway, nice job (｀• ω •´)b
